text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
MATERIAL CHANGES
IRM 1.4.7.1: Renamed the section Program Scope and Objectives. IRM 1.4.7.1, Program, Scope and Objectives. Added IRM 1.4.7.1.1, Background, IRM 1.4.7.1.2, Authority, and IRM 1.4.7.1.3, Acronyms.
IRM 1.4.7.2.4: Removed statement about full time members. Modiﬁed ﬁnal bullet to emphasize feedback and general maintenance. Removed bullets:

1.4.7.2.8: Added new section to reﬂect Compliance, Planning and Classiﬁcation activities, as the did not exist when this IRM section was last published.

IRM 1.4.7.4.1: Removed paragraphs (2) and (4) and renumbered the remaining paragraphs, to reﬂect the Knowledge Management’s migration from the TE/GE hosted Knowledge Networks to the Servicewide Knowledge Management platform.

EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
This document supersedes IRM 1.4.7, Resource Guide for Managers, TE/GE Knowledge Network (KM) Administration, dated February 7, 2017.
Tax Exempt and Government Entities
TE/GE Knowledge Management (KM) Administration 1.4.7

nization. TE/GE Knowledge Management materials reside on the Service Virtual Library. • Capture, compile and catalogue current technical knowledge relevant TE/GE functions, and maintain in a form easily accessible to TE/GE employees. • Consolidate, preserve and share TE/GE’s technical knowledge base. • Establish knowledge networks that connect employees and improve communication and collaboration. • Make timely technical assistance available to all TE/GE employees. • Ensure quality and consistency of technical positions taken and performed on behalf of TE/GE. (
) By Treasury Order
, the Secretary of the Treasury delegates to the missioner of Internal Revenue the responsibility for the enforcement of the Internal Revenue Laws. (
) Policy Statement
(IRM

) provides: a. The Internal Revenue Service will be a progressive organization. b. There will be a deﬁnite program to enhance the effectiveness of all elements of the Service. The program will be comprehensive in imaginative, yet realistic in design and will be so administered so as to provide vigorous and dedicated attention to making the Internal Service a truly forward thinking organization, one that will be by employees and the public alike as representing that which is best modern and progressive management. (
) This table lists acronyms used in this IRM and their deﬁnitions. C&L Communications and Liaison EEE The Associate Chief Counsel (Employee Beneﬁts, Exempt Organizations and Employment Taxes)

Capture, compile and catalogue current technical knowledge relevant TE/GE functions, and maintain in a form easily accessible to TE/GE employees. Consolidate, preserve and share TE/GE’s technical knowledge base. Establish knowledge networks that connect employees and improve communication and collaboration. Make timely technical assistance available to all TE/GE employees. Ensure quality and consistency of technical positions taken and performed on behalf of TE/GE.
Policy Statement
(IRM

) provides: a. The Internal Revenue Service will be a progressive organization. b. There will be a deﬁnite program to enhance the effectiveness of all elements of the Service. The program will be comprehensive in concept, imaginative, yet realistic in design and will be so administered so as to provide vigorous and dedicated attention to making the Internal Revenue Service a truly forward thinking organization, one that will be recognized by employees and the public alike as representing that which is best in modern and progressive management.
This table lists acronyms used in this IRM and their deﬁnitions.

• Ensure submitted suggestions are addressed. • Identify and set goals for the KM Area. • Coordinate ongoing KM staffing, solicitation, and hiring requirements. • Be the primary decision maker for KM postings, advice, and • Update the KM Area’s Action Plan with task status and secure Tier

Director approval, if appli- cable. (
) If there is no Senior Manager, the functional Director fulﬁlls the Senior Manager role. (

) A KM Manager: a. Oversees the KM team’s day-to-day operations b. Ensures the KM team meets its identiﬁed goals as established by the Senior Manager c. Ensures the KM team exhibits collaboration and knowledge sharing in activities. (

) Major duties include but aren’t limited to: • Promote a collaborative environment that: allows employees to and consider differing opinions; supports team building and diversity amongst participants. • Ensure Core Team and Extended Core Team members adhere to KM roles and responsibilities. • Manage work assignments and monitor workload. • Create an Action Plan that guides KM activities and ensures KM is regularly reviewed and updated for currency, relevance and quality and secures Senior Manager and Director approval, if applicable. • Help coordinate the Core and Extended Core Teams to develop and training materials, answer questions and reach consensus. • Offer the Extended Core Team learning opportunities in coordination with the employees’ Manager of Record. • Check-in regularly with Extended Core Team’s Manager of Record to discuss progress, workload, time management, etc. • Analyze trends on the Contact an Expert data and discussion forum identify new issues, areas requiring additional content development, potential topics for KM Events. • Review regularly the Contact an Expert tracker to ensure data is complete and ensure technical quality of responses. • Ensure Core Teams and Extended Core Teams are sufficiently trained on KM operations and technology. • Coordinate with other KM teams to develop training materials with Learning and Education (L&E) to promote cross-functional and engagement. • Collaborate with other KM Managers to share best practices and consistent operations. • Review submitted suggestions for KM, assign them, and ensure they are addressed. • Identify and follow up on questions outstanding more than
days.

1.4 Resource Guide for Managers
Resource Guide for • Get approval to post content. • Provide input on Extended Core Team members’ performance tions. • Coordinate KM events to avoid conﬂicts. • Review training recommendations. (

) The KM Manager may designate or be assigned a KM Lead for support in to-day operations. Depending on the KM team’s size and complexity, this may not be required. Typical lead duties may include: a. Set up internal team meetings. b. Monitor the Contact an Expert queue and assign them based on the Manager’s direction. c. Act as a liaison between the team and the KM Manager. d. Knowledge Base site administrator. Note: Duties are assigned based on the individual’s grade and level. (
) KM Core Team members participate in the day-to-day operations of a KM team. They help: a. Capture and develop content. b. Share expertise. c. Collaborate. (
) Major duties include but aren’t limited to: • Maintain content on KM Shar

oint sites and ensure it’s current. • Identify the need to collaboratively create new content and get items approved such as job aids, examination tools, Issue Snapshots, and forma language to post to the KM sites. • Work with KM Manager and KM Senior Manager to brief Executives emerging technical issues. • Communicate routinely with the ﬁeld and other stakeholders to stay abreast of new developments and emerging issues. • Be responsible for their own technical development and growth of expertise. • Track signiﬁcant developments such as new laws, industry guidance, etc. • Recommend training with Training Coordinators and L&E. • Communicate new developments and topics of interest to relevant TE/GE employees via email, meetings, Frequently Asked Questions Hot Topics, etc. • Plan, develop content and facilitating KM Events to share and engage in dialogue with employees. • Respond to questions and work with the Core and Extended Core Teams to answer them, if applicable. • Develop and routinely update FAQs based on questions received. • Monitor the website for feedback and general maintenance.

% of his/her time Core Team b. Supports one or more KM teams in some or all of the Core Team member duties in IRM
) c. May have varying levels of experience with KM technical issues. (
) The KM Manager assigns work to Extended Core Team members in tion with the employee’s own manager based on the: • employee’s availability • employee’s expertise • KM team needs (
) The Extended Core Team employee’s Manager of Record does functions including time and leave approval, routine performance and disciplinary actions. (
) Communications & Liaison (C&L) supports KM objectives through tions support. C&L helps with Shar
oint site support administration and & provides technological expertise. (C&L) (
) C&L supports technology for KM Shar

oint sites by doing these tasks, including but not limited to: • Submit system defects/errors and technology enhancements/ improvements from the feedback process to the Change Control • Be the central point of contact for submitting technology change requests (including requested prioritization) per the Change Control Process. • Do structural updates to KM Portal approved via the Change Control Process. See KM Portal. • Manage Permissions for KM Portal and troubleshoot any access problems. • Support KM Teams in using their Knowledge Bases and KM Portal effectively including conﬁguring internal document libraries, setting alerts, etc. • Offer basic user support and troubleshooting for using the KM (

) C&L also supports the KM teams using communication tools and processes doing these tasks, including but not limited to: • Edit TE/GE-wide communications on KM updates, events and presentations about KM activities and services. • Edit other communication materials as needed, such as newsletter articles or other KM communications. • Publish appropriate information on KM Portal, IRS.gov, and other communications once approved. • Edit KM training and communication materials for plain language make
compliant, as requested. (

Resource Guide for
The assigned TEGEDC advisor is involved in each KM team and utes to discussions on issue escalation. (

) The TEGEDC KM advisor’s primary responsibility: a. Provide timely legal advice to the KM teams. b. Identify issues to elevate to TE/GE and/or TEGEDC management or ordinate with other Chief Counsel functions. c. Review new content (such as training, issue snapshots, FAQs and guidelines). See IRM

) TEGEDC attorneys may: a. Participate in KM events. b. Give presentations. c. Attend KM meetings. d. Collaborate with the KM teams on suggested guidance. Note: TEGEDC isn’t involved in the day-to-day KM operational or man- agement and won’t post content to the KM sites. (
) KM Areas and Issue ID will coordinate at least annually to discuss and tax law or form changes and the impact on case classiﬁcation. (
) Collaboration with Issue ID will be to discuss tax law changes, identify and to develop new queries to identify issues related to such changes. (

) This coordination with Issue ID may include the sharing of training material being developed and suggestions for revised or new queries. and collaboration between the KM Areas and Issue ID are key in this effort assess tax law changes and the impact on CP&C’s work. (

) Each KM area develops its own goals and focus. KM areas are encouraged a. Be innovative in discussing and suggesting ways to achieve KM goals. b. Create an Action Plan to establish its focus for the upcoming year. (

) The Action Plan considers these TE/GE employees’ broader strategic and gathers their input: • TE/GE leadership • KM management • KM teams • Field managers • Key stakeholders (such as, other KM teams, TEGEDC site tors) (
) The team uses the Action Plan to sequence and prioritize work. They revisit and revise it as issues arise throughout the year. (

) The Action Plan should clearly identify what the KM area expects to accom- plish in an agreed upon time. It: a. Identiﬁes activities (for example, new, ongoing, proposed). b. Describes the activity.

) TE/GE KM operates in a collaborative environment. Key areas of include: Principles • Identifying trends • Maintaining site content • Communicating to employees • Hosting network events • Managing and maintaining Knowledge Libraries • Managing Hot Topics • Monitoring discussion forums and feedback items • Responding to technical questions (

) Collaboration within and across KM is essential to building and retaining support by all employees. Seeking diverse opinions and encouraging sions to arrive at consensus will ultimately: a. Lead to better ideas. b. Put the best position forward. c. Get buy-in from employees who see that their opinions are valued. (

) The Core Team and Extended Core Team should raise any recommended change that has a broader impact to the KM Manager for further review discussion. Decisions that impact content (such as, job aids, precedential etc.) and training should be worked within the teams to ensure the best mation is included in the Knowledge Library and there’s no duplication of (

Create or updating existing content.

1.4 Resource Guide for Managers
Resource Guide for (

) Managers and KM teams should be proactive and brief Executives on emerging technical issues. Prepare topics in a one-page brieﬁng. Describe issue, how the team has been involved, and what the challenges are. Managers should note this as an opportunity to highlight not only new or emerging issues, but also issues for which guidance decisions or have a signiﬁcant impact to the ﬁeld and we need increased awareness. (

) The Core Team identiﬁes and maintains the content on the KM Knowledge Bases to ensure it remains accessible to employees. The team: Base a. Does basic editorial and administrative quality assurance reviews such Maintenance as: checking for broken links, duplicate items,

compliance, etc. b. Looks for inconsistencies in resource categorization and information linking, and suggest new categorizations and taxonomy as additional content is posted and reviewed. c. Conducts regular content reviews of site content to ensure relevance the materials. (
) See IRM
for additional information on Content Management. (
) Communication, both external and internal, is a key responsibility of KM (
) Internal KM communications include interactions with Core and Extended team members and KM management. (

) Internal KM team meetings are held at least monthly or more often as mined by the KM Manager. The KM team meets periodically to: KM Team • Discuss workload. • Collaborate on complex questions. • Discuss opportunities to develop new technical content. (

) The KM Manager holds the meetings or may designate someone else to the meeting and may designate a note taker. The note taker posts meeting minutes on the site designated meeting minute location before the next scheduled meeting. (
) Prepare agendas for Team Meetings in advance. The KM Manager when appropriate. The meeting structure is ﬂexible to ensure that all new and pending items are adequately addressed. (

) The KM Team collects, analyzes, reports and communicates feedback from users and stakeholders to evaluate the KM team’s use and performance. on team: a. Evaluates potential action items. b. Works with the KM Managers to improve the KM site (including ting any system related suggestions through the Feedback Process). Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

compliance, etc. b. Looks for inconsistencies in resource categorization and information linking, and suggest new categorizations and taxonomy as additional content is posted and reviewed. c. Conducts regular content reviews of site content to ensure relevance of the materials.
1.4.7.4.4.1.1 (07-06-2022) Internal KM Team Meetings
Internal KM team meetings are held at least monthly or more often as deter- mined by the KM Manager. The KM team meets periodically to:
The KM Team collects, analyzes, reports and communicates feedback from users and stakeholders to evaluate the KM team’s use and performance. The
Works with the KM Managers to improve the KM site (including submit- ting any system related suggestions through the Feedback Process).

) The KM teams also collaborate with C&L to ensure IRS.gov is kept up to The KM teams may complete the Communication Request Form and relevant information to: a. Create new web pages on IRS.gov. b. Supplement existing web pages on IRS.gov (for example, adding a FAQ to an existing set of FAQs, updating cited law). c. Clarify information already available (for example, adding examples, ing text for plain language). d. Release an Issue Snapshot. e. Hold a webinar for external taxpayers. f. Create other outreach products. (
) Senior Managers and KM Managers must coordinate to minimize conﬂicts and work with C&L to ensure duplicate communications are not to the same audience. (

) The KM Team hosts regular KM events. The KM Manager should responsible individual(s) to: a. Prepare the agenda. b. Write an announcement (with link to Teams/Skype/Zoom/Saba and ference call number, if applicable). c. Post information to the KM Related Events section after the approves. Include the name of the event, a brief description, and supporting materials. d. For large or formal events, send a meeting invitation to *TE/GE Events to post to the Executive Calendar. (
) The purpose of KM events is to: • Share and receive technical expertise. • Discuss practical issue-based information for expanding technical knowledge. • Identify emerging issues and trends. (
) KM Event can include subject matter experts who are not KM team (
) Events should create an environment that: • Encourages sharing of ideas. • Helps enhance skills. • Allows employees to feel comfortable to speak up and share • Promotes two-way communications. (
) During the event, employees may:
(07-06-2022) Host Knowledge Management Events

b. Write an announcement (with link to Teams/Skype/Zoom/Saba and ference call number, if applicable). c. Post information to the KM Related Events section after the Manager approves. Include the name of the event, a brief description, and any supporting materials. d. For large or formal events, send a meeting invitation to

• Learn about an issue. • Ask questions about an issue they’re currently working on. • Interact with other examiners who have a similar issue. • Discuss the legal analysis of the issue. • Discuss the IRS position on the issue and how to apply it to a case. (
) This section gives guidelines to make sure KM content is: • relevant • accurate • easy to use (
) It also describes responsibilities to review, approve, and continually content. See Exhibit
for guidelines on content approval and mainte- nance. (
) Existing Content includes content that has been previously written and is in circulation. Example: Guidance and reference materials on IRS.gov, case law, and code. (
) If you’re uncertain if material has been previously reviewed and approved, treat it as new content (see IRM

) The KM team reviews existing content for accuracy, relevance, and and recommends its posting to the Knowledge Base. a. Fully vet documents before posting. b. Consider the need and reason for the document before posting- quality matters most over quantity. c. Post content that is current and gives employees a strong base from which to start their research. (Don’t post every available document - be discrete in what you consider the most relevant and useful (
) Links to general training and other reference materials are on the KM Virtual Library. (
) Whenever possible, link code, regs etc. on IRS.gov, GPO site, or a research site rather than posting a document with this information. (
) See IRM
for required review and approvals for existing content. (

) New content is original content the KM teams developed such as tools, training materials, or issue snapshots. Revised content is material that was previously existing content but has been revised. Revised content does not include formatting or grammatical changes. Any technical changes be reviewed by TEGEDC. The KM teams must identify existing content that requires updating, or new content that needs to be developed by:
Looking for commonly submitted questions to KM teams or on the Dis- cussion Forum.
Field reports or data illustrating which issues are being identiﬁed in ex- aminations.
Suggestions and feedback from KM site users. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
F
Learn about an issue.

for required review and approvals for existing content. (

Revised content does not include formatting or grammatical changes. Any technical changes should be reviewed by TEGEDC. Discuss content needs and document them in the KM Action Plan for approval (KM Team and Manager). Designate a project lead(s) (either a Core or Extended Core member) and help assemble a team (KM Senior Manager or Manager). The project lead tracks the progress of the content development: updates helps to complete it, and works with management when necessary. Include members of the Core Team, Extended Core Team, and other employees with expertise in the area, and representatives from other BODs when appropriate. Include TEGEDC representatives at the start to incorporate their feedback. Use existing template(s) (if available) to ensure consistency.

1.4 Resource Guide for Managers

Stagger reviews to distribute the workload over the course of the year. Designate content as current, requiring update, or requiring archiving. Add content requiring update to the KM Action Plan. Archive content per record retention procedures. Coordinate with the designated Information Resource Coordinator (IRC) for proper archiving, and check the record control schedule for retention requirements.

Be proactive in seeking feedback from the KM users on their for additional content or changes. KM teams are responsible for keeping the KM Knowledge Base up to date, including: • Hot Topics postings • Site Contact List • Hot Topics Discussion Forums • Feedback • Contact an Expert • Events • KM related links The purpose of Hot Topics is to keep KM users up to date on current ments. Hot Topics are posted by KM teams and will remain as long as the topic is relevant. Hot Topics should be approved by the KM Manager before posting. To learn of new items posted: a. Employees can set a speciﬁc alert for Hot Topics for a KM site. b. KM teams may send an email to employees to alert them that a new Topic was posted. c. Participate in Hot Topics Discussion Forums. IRM

The contact list contains contact information for KM Core Team and Core Team members as Knowledge Base contributors, administrators or site owners. The contact list includes contact information for users to easily KM team members. Update the list when there is a change in membership the latest contacts are available. KM Managers are listed in the Site Contacts.

) Hot Topics Discussions Forums are open to all users. Anyone may post comment; however, the KM Team must: a. Monitor the discussion forum. b. Review forums for relevancy and accuracy of the website content. Note: As with all other posted site content, make sure no personally information (PII) or sensitive but unclassiﬁed (SBU) information is the discussion forums. (
) Managers establish procedures for how their KM Team monitors the forums and consider: (cid:

) Assignment - Assign team members to monitor the forum discus- sions in one of these ways: • Rotating assignment - Team members take turns • KM Lead - If the KM team has a lead, he/she may be re- sponsible • Forum Patrol - Two members of the team share the re- sponsibility (cid:

) Frequency - Reviewing the discussion forums will vary by KM team based on its level of activity. Managers or Core Team members can create an alert to ensure that the person(s) assigned to monitoring the KM is(are) immediately aware of any new posts. (cid:

) Escalation - Escalate content that is questionable with respect to accuracy, professionalism, or sensitivity to KM management. KM managers can approve deleting or editing a post and direct teams on how to follow-up including notifying the individual whose post was removed or edited. The Core Team may immediately remove any blatantly incorrect or inappropriate content then promptly notify the KM Manager. Retain any material that is required to be kept for Records Retention (if not retained elsewhere) per IRM
and the current TE/GE Records Control Schedule (

1.4 Resource Guide for Managers
) KM teams should continuously seek feedback in these ways to better serve KM users: a. During KM events. b. Via the Provide Feedback function on the KM Knowledge Bases. c. In other ways. (
) To keep a record, document feedback using the Provide Feedback form on KM site. (

) KM teams should review all feedback they receive through the Provide Feedback function at least weekly. KM Managers should assign each item KM team member and follow up to ensure it’s addressed. Discuss impacting overall KM operations or other KM teams during the KM meetings. (
) Group suggestions on system errors or improvements that affect the site design, templates, or shared resources on a custom report for C&L. (

) KM teams may address feedback speciﬁc to their own site/topic, such as a broken link or developing or updating content. The teams may also help users to navigate the site or provide one-on-one basic training through a Content Contributor. (

) The “Contact an Expert” process describes how a user may request tion from the KM Team and how the team will respond to the inquiry. The process is: a. Primarily intended to answer questions after an employee has re- searched the KM sites and resources, discussed questions with peers and managers, and is looking for additional help. b. Limited to general questions on issues and procedures for case work. KM teams don’t review speciﬁc cases, develop IDRs, arguments, or exam documentation, or become involved in casework such as TAMs (

) To ensure consistency and promote collaboration and information sharing, existing Review Functions and others offering technical assistance should ordinate with the KM teams on issues that fall under one of the speciﬁed TE/GE areas. Coordination includes: • Communicating FAQs to the KM team to develop or revise content • Involving the KM team in discussions about complex, novel, or emerging issues that arise through the technical assistance process • Directing requestors to KM sites to familiarize them with available resources

Knowledge Management (KM) Administration 1.4.7
The Contact an Expert process from inquiry to initial contact should generally be completed within 5 business days:

Step Person/Actions Submit Inquiry Requestor:a.Selects the Contact an Expert feature on the KM site. b. Complete the ﬁelds on the Contact an Expert form Pre-Screen and Referral Manager or designated Assigner named as the point of contact: a. Read question. b. If you receive a simple question via call or email that you can answer imme- diately, answer it right away. If the question is something that should be tracked for trending, add it in as a formal question to Contact an Expert to document and track it and let Requestor know that it has been added. c. Assign to the proper KM team if mistakenly assigned to yours. Add notes and explain on the appropriate ﬁelds of the form. Assign Inquiry Assigner:a.Assign the inquiry to appro- priate Core or Extended Core Team member(s) from the Active Directory linked to Outlook. Assign to a Secondary Responder so members can learn and col- laborate. b. Complete the following ﬁelds on the form: Date Assigned, Assigned To - Primary, Assigned To - Secondary (not mandatory), Status (change to Assigned).
named as the point of contact: a. Read question. b. If you receive a simple question via call or email that you can answer imme

priate Core or Extended Core Team member(s) from the Active Directory linked to Outlook. Assign to a Secondary Responder so members can learn and col

Step Person/Actions Conﬁrm Receipt and Provide Responder: Email Requestor to: • Initial Response Conﬁrm receipt • Schedule an initial discus- sion to ensure the facts are accurate • Conﬁrm if additional research is needed Note: Your initial response can include existing guidance, self-help materials, forum discussions, etc. In some cases, this may be all that is required. The primary and secondary assignee should work inquiries together to knowledge share, collaborate, and ensure consistent positions.
TE/GE Knowledge Management (KM) Administration

Step Person/Actions Draft Response and Review Responder: Draft a response depending on the complexity of the question: a. Simple questions that have a standard response or a published position don’t require team collaboration to determine the answer. Email your answer and cc the Re- questor’s manager. b. Complex or unique questions that don’t have an established answer or resource require a team approach.•Togain additional input or expertise, post the drafted response to the team collaboration site, where the KM Team can review and build consensus on an ap- propriate response. • In about 5 days, Re- sponder(s) reviews feedback and incorpo- rates into the response. • If the question is par- ticularly complex or there are differing opinions, Responder may add the topic to an internal team meeting agenda. Note: It’s important to communi- cate with Requestor during this time to clarify and col- laborate possible answers.

Step Person/Actions Update form / Send response Responder:a.Complete the Inquiry Response ﬁeld. b. Email the response to Requestor. c. Post the ﬁnal response on the collaboration site in the designated library/folder using the team’s agreed ﬁle naming convention. d. Refer to the ﬁlename in the Inquiry Response ﬁeld so the team can ﬁnd the response for future, similar questions, trending analysis and management review. e. CC Requestor’s manager for information and to consider for similar issues.
Issue Snapshots: a. Give an overview of a tax issue. b. Identify resources that may help clarifying the topic further. An Issue Snapshot includes:
A brief description
Pertinent Internal Revenue Code sections, Treasury Regulations, resources (including any job aids)
Analysis of the issue
Determinations review or exam tips
Industry information, if applicable An Issue Snapshot is not intended to be:
A comprehensive analysis of an issue or multiple issues.

″ ″ Used as a pro forma position/discussion on an issue. An Issue Snapshot is a resource for technical knowledge that can be It’s a tool that helps achieve the KM goal of collecting, organizing and loguing knowledge. Issue Snapshots are posted in the Knowledge library on the IRS.gov reading room for external customers. Issue Snapshots require Counsel approval of the topic prior to Upon drafting of an Issue Snapshot, TEGEDC and Associate Chief Employee Beneﬁts, Exempt Organizations, and Employment Taxes (EEE) review and provide guidance. This guidance may include revisions to the Snapshot.
A comprehensive analysis of an issue or multiple ″ ″ Used as a pro forma position/discussion on an issue.

Items posted to the KM discussion forums are considered records and all plicable records retention standards must be followed.

Users are unable to delete or edit their own forum postings. Only KM Managers and KM Teams may delete postings. KM Teams and Managers should review the hot topic and discussion responses regularly to ensure that responses to answer the question(s) accurate and no case

Right click on the discussion thread and click “Print” – select PDF

) PII, SBU and return information are not permitted on any IRS Shar
oint site. Follow these procedures for an inadvertent disclosure on a KM site: (
) Questions received via Contact an Expert are viewable on the collaboration site, access to which is restricted to the KM Manager and the KM team. (

) If an unauthorized disclosure of return information, SBU or PII is identiﬁed, via Contact KM Manager immediately contacts the requestor’s Manager to begin the Expert thorized disclosure reporting process (see IRM
, IRM
, and PGLD’s Data Protection and Inadvertent Disclosures procedures).
PII, SBU and return information are not permitted on any IRS SharePoint Follow these procedures for an inadvertent disclosure on a KM site:
Questions received via Contact an Expert are viewable on the collaboration site, access to which is restricted to the KM Manager and the KM team.

If an unauthorized disclosure of return information, SBU or PII is identiﬁed, the KM Manager immediately contacts the requestor’s Manager to begin the unau- thorized disclosure reporting process (see IRM
, IRM
, and PGLD’s Data Protection and Inadvertent Disclosures procedures).
Note: Return information includes most case-speciﬁc facts and information and is not limited to the taxpayer’s name, address, SSN, date of birth, or other in- formation on the taxpayer’s return.
Note: PII includes all information that, viewed separately or along with other avail- able information, can be used to identify a unique taxpayer.

Caution: Therefore, if you see case-speciﬁc facts on the discussion forum, or any facts that could be used to identify a unique taxpayer, assume they are return information unless the user has clearly indicated he/she created hypothetical facts.

a. Document an audit log stored on the KM team’s Collaboration Site: the name of the requestor, the date submitted, the ID number in the tracking system, the general nature of the disclosure, and actions taken to address it. b. Move the submitted question (including the return information, SBU or PII data) to the designed secured electronic folder on the shared server. c. Remove the return information, SBU or PII from the KM website. d. Notify the site collection administrator so the item can be deleted perma
nently from the recycle bin.
1.4.7.9.2.2 (07-06-2022) Unauthorized Disclosures via the Hot Topics Discussion
Note: Return information includes most case-speciﬁc facts and information and is not limited to the taxpayer’s name, address, SSN, date of birth, or other in- formation on the taxpayer’s return.
Note: PII includes all information that, viewed separately or along with other available information, can be used to identify a unique taxpayer.

Caution: Therefore, if you see case-speciﬁc facts on the discussion forum, or any facts that could be used to identify a unique taxpayer, assume they are return information unless the user has clearly indicated he or she created hypothetical facts for purposes of the forum.

If at any point a decision cannot be resolved by consensus, OR if the position is not applicable, it will elevated to the next level.

Directors Deﬁnitions Director, EP Rulings and Agreements R – Responsible: “The Doer.” This is the individual(s) who actually complete the task and is responsible for the action. Director, EO Rulings and Agreements A – Approver: “The Buck Stops Here.” This is the individual who is ultimately answerable for the activity or decision. Director, Government Entities C – Consulted: “In the Loop.” This individual(s) is consulted and reviews the material prior to a ﬁnal decision or action. This incorporates two-way communication. I – Informed: “Keep in the Picture.” This is the individual(s) who needs to be informed after a decision or action is taken.
